findings.title: Missing access control on withdrawal functions
findings.explanation: The functions withdrawTokens and withdrawEther are declared public with no access control. Any external account can invoke them, potentially triggering withdrawals at arbitrary times.
findings.fix_suggestion: Introduce an onlyOwner modifier and apply it to both withdrawTokens and withdrawEther to restrict execution to the contract owner.

findings.title: Unbounded loop and unsafe external call in getTokens
findings.explanation: The getTokens function accepts an arbitrary loop count (num) and makes a low-level call to an external address each iteration. A malicious contract at addr can consume excessive gas or revert repeatedly, causing a denial-of-service through gas exhaustion or constant reverts.
findings.fix_suggestion: Validate and cap the num parameter, restrict or validate the target address, and avoid unbounded low-level calls. Consider using a fixed gas stipend or safe iteration patterns.

findings.title: Unchecked return value on ERC20 transfer
findings.explanation: The call to tc.transfer(owner, tc.balanceOf(this)) returns a boolean success flag that is ignored. If the token contract returns false, the transfer failure will go unnoticed and tokens will remain stuck in EtherGet.
findings.fix_suggestion: Check the return value of the transfer call, for example: require(tc.transfer(owner, tc.balanceOf(this))), to ensure the token transfer succeeds.
